articles.headline: Out of Prison, and Staying Out, After 3rd Strike in California
articles.snippet: Convicts released after the state eased its three-strikes law in 2012 have returned to crime at a remarkably low rate.
articles.abstract: Convicts released after the state eased its three-strikes law in 2012 have returned to crime at a remarkably low rate.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — William Taylor III, once a lifer in state prison for two robbery convictions and the intent to sell a small packet of heroin, was savoring a moment he had scarcely dared to imagine: his first day alone, in a place of his own.

articles.headline: F.C.C. Approves Net Neutrality Rules, Classifying Broadband Internet Service as a Utility
articles.snippet: The agency’s 3-2 vote is intended to ensure a level playing field for Internet content providers, with no so-called pay-to-play fast lanes.
articles.abstract: The agency’s 3-2 vote is intended to ensure a level playing field for Internet content providers, with no so-called pay-to-play fast lanes.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Communications Commission voted on Thursday to regulate broadband Internet service as a public utility, a milestone in regulating high-speed Internet service into American homes.
articles.byline: By Rebecca R. Ruiz and Steve Lohr

articles.headline: Targeted by U.S. Prosecutor, Hedge Fund Fights Back
articles.snippet: The suit may be a long shot, but it comes as Preet Bharara’s image as an invincible prosecutor — racking up convictions on Wall Street — is beginning to fray.
articles.abstract: The suit may be a long shot, but it comes as Preet Bharara’s image as an invincible prosecutor — racking up convictions on Wall Street — is beginning to fray.
articles.lead_paragraph: On a crisp fall morning, F.B.I. agents staged a surprise raid of three hedge funds, feeding the growing national reputation of the prosecutor Preet Bharara as the new sheriff of Wall Street.
articles.byline: By Matthew Goldstein, Ben Protess and Andrew Ross Sorkin

articles.headline: In Greece, Bailout May Hinge on Pursuing Tycoons
articles.snippet: Athens promised to go after wealthy tax evaders, but that’s the easy part. What’s harder is reshaping tycoons’ domination of parts of the economy.
articles.abstract: Athens promised to go after wealthy tax evaders, but that’s the easy part. What’s harder is reshaping tycoons’ domination of parts of the economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATHENS — As he sifted recently through a sheaf of Greek bank accounts held by executives, politicians and other members of the Greek elite, Panagiotis Nikoloudis, the nation’s new anti-corruption czar, was struck by some troubling numbers.

articles.headline: As Hedge Fund Returns Falter, Money Continues to Flow In
articles.snippet: Despite their performance record, the promise of higher returns with lower risk — or even zero risk — beckons.
articles.abstract: Despite their performance record, the promise of higher returns with lower risk — or even zero risk — beckons.
articles.lead_paragraph: Another year, and another mediocre performance by hedge funds, to put it kindly. The Barclay Hedge Fund Index gained a meager 2.89 percent in 2014, while the Standard & Poor’s 500-stock index gained over 13 percent and the Barclays United States Aggregate Bond Index rose over 5 percent.

articles.headline: ‘Jihadi John’ From ISIS Execution Videos Was Under Watch by British Intelligence
articles.snippet: The man, identified as Mohammed Emwazi, came to the attention of the authorities in 2009, when they thought he was going to fight with Al Shabab.
articles.abstract: The man, identified as Mohammed Emwazi, came to the attention of the authorities in 2009, when they thought he was going to fight with Al Shabab.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Mohammed Emwazi was 6 when his parents moved to West London from his birthplace in Kuwait, and he seems to have lived a normal life, studying hard and graduating in computer sciences from the University of Westminster in 2009.

articles.headline: Dutch Offer Preview of Net Neutrality
articles.snippet: As with the rules adopted by the F.C.C., the Netherlands demands that wireless and fixed-line broadband providers treat all Internet traffic equally.
articles.abstract: As with the rules adopted by the F.C.C., the Netherlands demands that wireless and fixed-line broadband providers treat all Internet traffic equally.
articles.lead_paragraph: THE HAGUE — When Bruno Leenders takes the 50-minute train ride to Amsterdam, he likes to stream blues and funk music through his smartphone. At home, Mr. Leenders, a Dutch technology consultant, watches Steven Seagal action movies on Netflix. Between meetings, he dashes off a few emails.

articles.headline: Move to Ban a Bullet Adds to Its Appeal
articles.snippet: The Obama administration has proposed banning the manufacture and sale of a popular bullet used in AR-15 semiautomatic rifles, a move that has enraged gun rights advocates.
articles.abstract: The Obama administration has proposed banning the manufacture and sale of a popular bullet used in AR-15 semiautomatic rifles, a move that has enraged gun rights advocates.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama’s administration has proposed banning the manufacture and sale of one of the most popular bullets used in AR-15 semiautomatic rifles, a move that has enraged gun-rights advocates and caused a run on the ammunition at gun shops across the country.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Julie Hirschfeld Davis

articles.headline: The White and Gold (No, Blue and Black!) Dress That Melted the Internet
articles.snippet: White and gold, or blue and black? The debate over the colors of a dress set off a social media conflagration that few were able to resist.
articles.abstract: White and gold, or blue and black? The debate over the colors of a dress set off a social media conflagration that few were able to resist.
articles.lead_paragraph: The mother of the bride wore white and gold. Or was it blue and black?

articles.headline: Making Money Decisions When You Lose Your Job
articles.snippet: About 1.7 million people lose their jobs every month, creating a hugely stressful situation and requiring potentially life-altering choices.
articles.abstract: About 1.7 million people lose their jobs every month, creating a hugely stressful situation and requiring potentially life-altering choices.
articles.lead_paragraph: The numbers are striking: About 1.7 million people, on average, lose their jobs every month.

articles.headline: Mutual Suspicion Mars Tech Trade With China
articles.snippet: With China and the United States wary of the other’s digital espionage, American tech companies are caught in the middle.
articles.abstract: With China and the United States wary of the other’s digital espionage, American tech companies are caught in the middle.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — At an elegant guesthouse here recently, China’s top Internet regulator entertained ambassadors and diplomats with platters of tempura and roast on a spit, unusual lavishness in an era of official austerity in China, to celebrate the Chinese New Year.
articles.byline: By Jane Perlez and Paul Mozur
